title: John with a sudden case of Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy
clinical_history: John is a 38-year-old construction worker who presented to the clinic with rapidly progressive weakness in his lower extremities. Approximately one week prior, John experienced a mild upper respiratory infection which he believes is unrelated. His symptoms began three days ago with tingling and weakness in his feet that quickly progressed to his calves and thighs. By today, he cannot walk without help and has difficulty lifting his arms. He reports no sensory loss nor changes in bowel or bladder function. John is very concerned as his symptoms have escalated rapidly, and he has noticed significant muscle wasting in a short amount of time.
aggrevating_factors: physical exertion, walking, and attempting to climb stairs
picture: [insert image of a human figure highlighting lower and upper limb]
past_history: John has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. He has no previous neurological or musculoskeletal complaints and generally leads an active lifestyle due to his work.
medical_history: other than hypertension, he is generally healthy. No prior history of neurological disorders. Recent mild upper respiratory infection.
personal_history: John is married with two young children. As a construction worker, he takes pride in his physical abilities and is worried about his capacity to provide for his family due to his current condition.
imaging: Electromyography (EMG) shows markedly reduced motor nerve conduction velocities and amplitudes, consistent with motor axonal damage.
